info.game_comments:
2004-A Kids Week game 4.
From Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: The youngest branch of the U.S. military, it was created soon after World War II

(2, 1).clue: The most basic command; you may have to push down on the dog's hindquarters to teach it

(4, 1).clue: In 1870 William J. Canby claimed this woman, his grandmother, made the first U.S. flag; few now support his claim

(5, 1).clue: This song by Christina Aguilera says, "You are" this, "no matter what they say" & "in every single way"

(1, 2).clue: This empire ruled in what is now Mexico during the 1400s & early 1500s

(2, 2).clue: Many puppies first meet this professional at age 8 weeks, for worming & shots

(3, 2).clue: It's the continent where you'll find the countries of Mauritania, Equatorial Guinea & Zambia

(4, 2).clue: It's the total number of red stripes on the American flag

(5, 2).clue: This teen from Orlando proved that she was "So Real" with hits like "Candy"

(1, 3).clue: On Sept. 2, 1864 General Sherman captured this city, subsequently burning much of it to the ground

(2, 3).clue: A puppy of this dogged breed of dog is seen here

(3, 3).clue: Lebanon, Italy & Spain all border this large sea

(4, 3).clue: In 1840 the U.S. flag first flew over this continent during the Charles Wilkes expedition

(5, 3).clue: This performer had a song on the "Scooby-Doo" soundtrack; he shares his name with a character in the movie"She call meMr. Boombastic /Say me fantastic /Touch me on me back, she say..."

(1, 4).clue: In 336 B.C., at age 20, he became king of the Macedonians

(2, 4).clue: Healthy Morsels, one version of this Purina brand, includes those doggy favorites peas & carrots

(3, 4).clue: Covering almost 30,000 square miles, this country consists of the northern third of the Island of Great Britain

(4, 4).clue: On August 3, 1949 Pres. Truman signed a resolution designating this date as Flag Day

(5, 4).clue: "Uh Huh" & "Girlfriend" are hit songs by this foursome of Omarion, J Boog, Raz B & Lil Fizz

(6, 4).clue: The highest quality grade of beef

(1, 5).clue: It's the first name of Italian navigator Vespucci, who made several trips to the New World around 1500

(3, 5).clue: Named for a former U.S. president, this mountain peak in Denali N.P. is the highest point in the United States

(4, 5).clue: On July 20, 1969 astronauts first planted the U.S. flag on the Moon in an area called the Sea of this

(5, 5).clue: In April 2003 this rapper topped the Billboard chart with his song "In Da Club"

(6, 5).clue: This variety of performer dates back to the Ancient Greeks

(1, 1).clue: It's the number of the current year rounded to the nearest thousand

(2, 1).clue: (Mom Cheryl of the Clue Crew tries to sound "hip" & "with it".) What is up, dawg?  Don't I sound like this "American Idol" judge and Grammy-winning producer, dawg?

(3, 1).clue: Like mother, like daughter: her daughter Irene Joliot-Curie also won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry

(4, 1).clue: The personal computer,the light bulb,the transistor radio

(5, 1).clue: The Bulls are beastly when they slam it down in this NBA home city

(6, 1).clue: This wormlike creature is a butterfly or moth in the larval stage

(1, 2).clue: A foot & a half equals this many inches

(2, 2).clue: (Mom Cheryl of the Clue Crew tries to be helpful.  But she just isn't.)  I'm sure my son, Alec, was grateful when I told him to pull up his pants so this pugilistic items wouldn't show & embarrass him

(3, 2).clue: Researchers say this man killed in 1865 might have been so tall and thin due to a rare condition called Marfan's syndrome

(5, 2).clue: The NFL's Dolphins ride the surf to glory in this city

(6, 2).clue: This small, heavy object, often made of glass, is designed to keep stuff from blowing off your desk

(1, 3).clue: As a ratio, 7 is to 10 as this is to 30

(2, 3).clue: (Oh-oh!  Mom Cheryl is no Beyonce or Lucy Liu.)  Hey ya!  The rhymes are tight & I'm shaking it just like one of these in that OutKast song

(3, 3).clue: This great German composer of "Fur Elise" was born in Bonn in 1770

(4, 3).clue: World War I,the U.S. Civil War,the War of 1812

(5, 3).clue: In the NHL, the Bruins bruise up the opposition when in this home city

(6, 3).clue: Doctors can look at blood cells under this magnifying instrument

(1, 4).clue: If you get 12 questions right out of the 20 on your history test, you got this percent correct

(2, 4).clue: (Mom Cheryl of the Clue Crew is left incredulous by fashion.)  I can't believe my kids want clothes from this "Farm"--they're not the least bit chubby

(3, 4).clue: This French military leader was a major general in the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War

(5, 4).clue: This Texas city hosts the WNBA's Comets & the NBA's Rockets, y'all

(6, 4).clue: Ross Powers won the men's superpipe at the 2003 U.S. Open in this sport

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows an inequality on the chalkboard.)  For a set of odd numbers described thusly, they're the three possible values for n

(2, 5).clue: (Mom Cheryl of the Clue Crew exhorts you to some juvenile fun.)  Come on, let's hit the half pipe & do a few tail slides, like this guy who landed the first ever 900 at the X Games

(3, 5).clue: In Islamic tradition, Bilqis is the name of Solomon's guest, the queen of this

(5, 5).clue: The NHL's Mighty Ducks get off skate free playing their home games in this city

(6, 5).clue: It's a list of the sources you used when writing a research paper

(0, 0).clue: 11-year-old Frank Epperson invented this by accident when his fruit drink froze after being left outside overnight
